description: Sgurr nan Ceathreamhnan is a magnificent mountain, the culminating point of a series of fine ridges. It is at the very heart of the wild area at the head of Glen Affric - making it one of the remotest peaks in Scotland - and most walkers will need an overnight stay to make the ascent. Sgurr nan Ceathreamhnan can be climbed in conjunction with Mullach nan Dheiragain and An Socach.
name: Sgurr nan Ceathreamhnan
region: Loch Duich to Loch Ness, South of Loch Mullardoch

description: Sgurr nan Clach Geala is a magnificent mountain, a fine north-south ridge with a stunning east face, a long wall of broken crags. The approach is normally made via the foot of Loch a'Bhraoin. Sgurr nan Clach Geala can be climbed with Meall a'Chrasgaidh and Sgurr nan Each.
name: Sgurr nan Clach Geala
region: Loch Maree to Loch Broom and Garve

description: Sgurr nan Coireachan is a steep mixture of grassy and rocky slopes, giving a tough ascent from Glen Dessary. If the ridge is followed to its termination on Sgurr na Ciche, however, it is merely the warm-up for the exertions to follow. Sgurr nan Coireachan can be climbed with Garbh Chioch Mhor and Sgurr na Ciche.
name: Sgurr nan Coireachan (Glenn Dessary)

description: Sgurr nan Coireachan is one of a pair of Munros at the head of Glen Finnan. Both are fine, rocky peaks with great views and some of the character of neighbouring Knoydart. Sgurr nan Coireachan can be climbed with Sgurr Thuilm.
name: Sgurr nan Coireachan (Glenfinnan)

description: Sgurr nan Conbhairean is a shy, dome-shaped mountain above Loch Cluanie but set back too far to be seen from the road. It is the highest of a group of three Munros that make an enjoyable round. As mentioned, Sgurr nan Conbhairean can be climbed with the other two Munros, which are Carn Ghluasaid and Sail Chaorainn.
name: Sgurr nan Conbhairean
region: Loch Duich to Loch Ness, South of Loch Mullardoch

description: Sgurr nan Each is a Munro on the south ridge of Sgurr nan Clach Geala. It takes the form of an elegant 's'-shaped ridge with steep flanks. Sgurr nan Each can be climbed with Meall a'Chrasgaidh and Sgurr nan Clach Geala.
name: Sgurr nan Each
region: Loch Maree to Loch Broom and Garve

description: The southernmost peak in the Cuillin, Sgurr nan Eag is on one of the more straightforward sections of ridge though it does still require scrambling skills. This section of the ridge continues out to the terminal peak of Gars-bheinn and its position above the sea gives it stupendous views. Sgurr nan Eag can be climbed with Sgurr Dubh Mor.
name: Sgurr nan Eag

description: Sgurr nan Gillean is commonly regarded as the finest of the Skye Cuillin. A magnificent pyramidal peak, it has three main ridges. The easiest is open to keen scramblers only whilst the other two ridges are graded rock-climbs. Sgurr nan Gillean can be climbed with Am Basteir and Bruach na Frithe.
name: Sgurr nan Gillean

description: Sgurr Thuilm is one of the two Glenfinnan Munros. A fine rocky peak of great character, the views are magnificent with lochs and steep mountains in all directions. Sgurr Thuilm can be climbed with Sgurr nan Coireachan.
name: Sgurr Thuilm

description: Slioch is one of the most familiar mountains in the Highlands, with the view of the mountain across Loch Maree adorning countless calendars and brochures. It is also a fine viewpoint over the Fisherfield Forest to the north.
name: Slioch
region: Loch Maree to Loch Broom and Garve

description: Spidean a'Choire Leith is the highest summit of mighty Liathach. The mountain is exceptionally well defended by cliffs and buttresses and there are very few possible routes of ascent - and even these are steep and scrambly. The ridge on both sides of the summit is nothing short of magnificent. Spidean a'Choire Leith can be climbed with Mullach an Rathain.
name: Spidean a'Choire Leith (Liathach)

description: Spidean Coire nan Clach was promoted to Munro status in 1997 to become Beinn Eighe's second Munro. Spidean Coire nan Clach can be climbed with Ruadh-stac Mor
name: Spidean Coire nan Clach (Beinn Eighe)

description: Spidean Mialach is one of a pair of Munros on the north side of Loch Quoich. They make an excellent walk with fine stalkers paths on their lower slopes. Spidean Mialach can be climbed with Gleouraich.
name: Spidean Mialach

description: Sron a'Choire Ghairbh is the higher of the two Munros on the north side of Loch Lochy, rising above the forestry as seen from the south side of the loch. Its rounded summit has steep flanks and corries. Sron a'Choire Ghairbh can be climbed with Meall na Teanga.
name: Sron a'Choire Ghairbh

description: A twin to neighbouring Stob Coire Easain, Stob a'Choire Mheadhoin is part of a huge north-south ridge. It looks a fine pyramid when seen from around Moy its central position and height makes it a good viewpoint. Stob a'Choire Mheadhoin can be climbed with Stob Coire Easain.
name: Stob a'Choire Mheadhoin

description: Stob a'Choire Odhair may not be well-known by name, but it is a familiar sight as the dome-shaped mountain rising behind the lochs in the frequently-photographed view across Rannoch Moor. It is a fine viewpoint for looking out over the vast, wild emptyness of the moor. Stob a'Choire Odhair can be climbed with Stob Ghabhar.
name: Stob a'Choire Odhair
region: Loch Leven to Connel Bridge and Glen Lochy

description: Stob Ban is a fine cone-shaped mountain almost hidden behind the much higher Grey Corries range.
name: Stob Ban (Grey Corries)

description: Stob Ban is a very steep and sharply peaked Munro, one of the finest peaks in the Mamores. It is well seen from many points in lower Glen Nevis. Stob Ban can be climbed with Mullach nan Coirean.
name: Stob Ban (Mamores)

description: Stob Binnein is joined to its slightly higher twin Ben More and seldom thought of on its own; however it is actually the finer of the two summits. It can be approached separately from the south as well as the more usual combination from the north. Stob Binnein can be climbed with Ben More.
name: Stob Binnein

description: Stob Choire Claurigh is the highest of the Grey Corries, and its fine peak appears covered in scree in distant views. The range actually makes for a classic ridgewalk. Stob Choire Claurigh can be climbed with Stob Coire an Laoigh, Sgurr Choinnich Mor and Stob Ban.
name: Stob Choire Claurigh

description: Stob Coir' an Albannaich is one of the fine range of mountains on the south side of Glen Etive. It has a very fine summit right on the edge of a steep crag and it gives an enjoyable traverse. Stob Coir'an Albannaich can be climbed with Meall nan Eun.
name: Stob Coir'an Albannaich
region: Loch Leven to Connel Bridge and Glen Lochy

description: Stob Coire a'Chairn has a fine situation where the airy An Gearanach ridge meets the main spine of the Mamores. This area has some of the best ridgewalking in Scotland. Stob Coire a'Chairn can be climbed with An Gearanach, Am Bodach and Sgurr a'Mhaim.
name: Stob Coire a'Chairn

description: Stob Coire an Laoigh is the second of the Grey Corries peaks, set on a magnificent ridgewalk. The approaches to this peak are long and the Grey Corries traverse is not to be taken lightly. Stob Coire an Laoigh can be climbed with Stob Coire Claurigh, Sgurr Choinnich Mor and Stob Ban.
name: Stob Coire an Laoigh

description: A twin to neighbouring Stob a'Choire Mheadhoin, Stob Coire Easain shows a steep face to the northeast. This lengthy ridge lies between the deep trench of Loch Treig - traversed by the West Highland railway line - and the Lairig Leacach pass. Stob Coire Easain can be climbed with Stob a'Choire Mheadhoin.
name: Stob Coire Easain

description: Stob Coire Raineach - the northern summit of Buachaille Etive Beag - became a Munro in its own right in 1997. Its broad summit has great views of the Aonach Eagach. Stob Coire Raineach can be climbed with Stob Dubh.
name: Stob Coire Raineach (Buachaille Etive Beag)
region: Loch Leven to Connel Bridge and Glen Lochy

description: Stob Coire Sgreamhach is really part of the Bidean nam Bian massif but became a Munro in its own right in 1997. This fine summit is situated where the Beinn Fhada ridge joins the main ridge across the back of Bidean. Beinn Fhada is tricky terrain - particularly in descent - and the Lost Valley is the route usually used, involving a steep and eroded climb up scree. Stob Coire Sgreamhach can be climbed with Bidean nam Bian.
name: Stob Coire Sgreamhach
region: Loch Leven to Connel Bridge and Glen Lochy

description: Stob Coire Sgriodain is a steep sided ridge high above the glacial trench of Loch Treig. It is usually climbed in combination with neighbouring Chno Dearg.
name: Stob Coire Sgriodain

description: Stob Daimh (misspelt Diamh on some OS maps) is a fine peak, but is normally ascended as part of a circuit around Coire Cruachan with its majestic neighbour, Ben Cruachan.
name: Stob Daimh
region: Loch Leven to Connel Bridge and Glen Lochy

description: Stob Dearg is the highest and finest peak of Buachaille Etive Mor, and one of the most famous sights of the Highlands. The mountain presents a remarkable pyramid of rock to travellers along the A82 across Rannoch Moor. Stob Dearg can be climbed with Stob na Broige.
name: Stob Dearg (Buachaille Etive Mor)
region: Loch Leven to Connel Bridge and Glen Lochy

description: The higher of the two Munros on Buachaille Etive Beag, Stob Dubh is a fine summit on a grand section of ridge, overlooking Loch Etive. Stob Dubh can be climbed with Stob Coire Raineach.
name: Stob Dubh (Buachaille Etive Beag)
region: Loch Leven to Connel Bridge and Glen Lochy

description: Stob Ghabhar is the finest peak of the Black Mount range, with narrow rocky ridges, steep cliffs and deep corries. It is a familiar sight seen across the lochans of Rannoch Moor from the A82. Stob Ghabhar can be climbed with Stob a'Choire Odhair.
name: Stob Ghabhar
region: Loch Leven to Connel Bridge and Glen Lochy

description: Stob na Broige is the summit at the Glen Etive end of Buachaille Etive Mor. It was promoted to become a separate Munro in 1997 when means that most baggers now traverse the whole ridge. Stob na Broige can be climbed with Stob Dearg.
name: Stob na Broige (Buachaille Etive Mor)
region: Loch Leven to Connel Bridge and Glen Lochy

description: Stob Poite Coire Ardair is a ridge on the opposite side of the Window from Creag Meagaidh. It offers fine views across the spectacular cliffs of Coire Ardair, and has steep broken crags on its southern flanks. Stob Poite Coire Ardair can be climbed with Carn Liath and Creag Meagaidh.
name: Stob Poite Coire Ardair

description: Stuc a'Chroin is a steep and rocky peak, involving a scramble when ascended from neighbouring Ben Vorlich.
name: Stuc a'Chroin

description: Stuchd an Lochain is an enjoyable mountain with a fine northern corrie enclosing the almost circular Lochan nan Cat. It is usually climbed via a very short route from Loch an Daimh to the north but can also be approached from Pubil in upper Glen Lyon
name: Stuchd an Lochain

description: The Cairnwell is a prominent cone-shaped mountain when seen from the south on the drive up the Cairnwell Pass. It is a great viewpoint, but the summit has been ruined by the construction of communications masts whilst its slopes are scattered with skiing impedimentia. The Cairnwell can be climbed with Carn Aosda and Carn a'Gheoidh.
name: The Cairnwell
region: Forest of Atholl to Braemar and Blairgowrie

description: The Devil's Point is a bare pyramid of rock which guards the entrance to the Lairig Ghru from the south. From other directions its true nature as the southern termination of Cairn Toul is more apparent. The Devil's Point can be climbed with Cairn Toul, Sgor an Lochain Uaine and Braeriach.
name: The Devil's Point

description: The Saddle (An Diollaid in Gaelic) is the finest mountain in Kintail. Its fine summit has a whole batch of magnificent ridges, the pick of them all being the celebrated Forcan Ridge, one of the airiest scrambles in the Highlands. The Saddle can be climbed with Sgurr na Sgine.
name: The Saddle

description: Toll Creagach is an undistinguished dome-like summit between Glen Affric and Loch Mullardoch, with shallow corries on its flanks. Toll Creagach can be climbed with a'Choinich.
name: Toll Creagach
region: Loch Duich to Loch Ness, South of Loch Mullardoch

description: Tolmount looks a fine cone-like peak when seen from Loch Callater; otherwise it is a twin to its close neighbour Tom Buidhe - a simple rounded dome-like upthrust on the wide Mounth plateau. Tolmount can be climbed wih Tom Buidhe.
name: Tolmount

description: Tom a'Choinich is an eastward extension of the Carn Eige range, an 'e'-shaped junction of three ridges above Glen Affric. It is a far finer peak than its lumpy neighbour Toll Creagach. Tom a'Choinich can be climbed with Toll Creagach.
name: Tom a'Choinich
region: Loch Duich to Loch Ness, South of Loch Mullardoch

description: Tom Buidhe is a featureless dome-like upswelling on the vast Mounth plateau, looking nothing like a mountain from any direction. It is nearly always climbed with its neighbour Tolmount, and can be ascended from Glen Callater, Glen Doll or from the Cairnwell Pass.
name: Tom Buidhe

description: Tom na Gruagaich, formerly a Top, was promoted to become the second Munro of Beinn Alligin in 1997. It has sensational views over the sea to Skye and for most walkers is the start of the sensational traverse of the mountain. Tom na Gruagaich can be climbed with Sgurr Mhor.
name: Tom na Gruagaich (Beinn Alligin)
